One should only say that one restrains the future, and it is definitely not said that one restrains the past and present.
Do all those who obtain moral discipline or immorality obtain them from all sentient beings, from all parts, and from all causes?

A verse says:

Here, we will explain this in terms of the latter three causes.ğŸ”½There is one type of person who abides in the precepts, who obtains the precepts in relation to all sentient beings, but not by all aspects and not by all causes, namely, those who, with a lesser, middling, or superior mind, receive the precepts of the lay devotee or novice monk.

There is one type of person who abides in the precepts, who obtains the precepts in relation to all sentient beings, by all causes but not by all aspects, namely, those who, with the three types of mind, receive the precepts of the lay devotee, the one-day upavÄsa precepts, or the novice monk.

There is no one who does not universally obtain the precepts with regard to all sentient beings, because one only obtains the precepts by abiding in a good attitude toward all sentient beings, otherwise it is not so, because an evil attitude is not completely eliminated.

If a person does not make five kinds of fixed limits, then he can receive the precepts of individual liberation, namely, fixed limits with regard to sentient beings, members, places, times, and conditions.
Fixed limits with regard to sentient beings means thinking, I will only abstain from killing and so forth with regard to a certain class of sentient beings.

Fixed limits with regard to times means thinking, I will only be able to abstain from killing and so forth for a month and so forth.

One who receives the precepts in this way does not obtain the precepts, but only precepts-like good conduct.
How can one obtain the precepts with regard to objects that are not able to be transgressed?

The attainment of non-restraint is definitely from all sentient beings and karmic paths. There is no one who has a small portion of the realm or who does not have all the branches of non-restraint.

It is reasonable that one obtains all the restraints in the realm of sentient beings, because one obtains them through the superior intention of universally wishing to benefit and bring happiness to sentient beings. Because moral discipline and immorality exist only where there is shame and conscience, or their opposites.

The sages say that in these there is applied thought, sustained thought, etc., and they are called moving.

The Sutra of Unmoving says that they are called unmoving because they can induce an unmoving retribution.
How can a moving concentration induce an unmoving retribution?

Even though in this concentration there is movement due to calamities and dangers, still, as far as the retribution of action is concerned, it is not the same as the realm of desire, where there is movement and change, and for that reason it is called unmoving.
This means that in the realm of desire, action that should produce another realm or mode of birth may be experienced in this realm or mode of birth because of special conditions.

This means that there are actions that can produce external and internal wealth, status, physical form, size, color, strength, happiness, etc., and these actions should produce retribution in the heavens, etc.
But because of the power of special conditions, these actions may produce retribution in the human realm, etc.

The karmas of the other stages and realms of the form and formless realms cannot be transformed into the retribution of other stages and realms. The retribution of karmas is definitely established as immovable.
Also, a scripture says:
There are three kinds of karmas, those that accord with pleasant feeling, etc.
What are their characteristics?
A verse says:ğŸ”½Good karma up to the third stage accords with pleasant feeling.

Therefore, there are five kinds of feeling in accordance with feeling, namely, intrinsic nature, association,
and the difference between the object, ripening, and manifestation.
The treatise says:
Among all good karmas, from the desire realm up to the third meditation, it is called karma that accords with pleasant feeling, because all pleasant feelings are only up to this point.
Bad karma is called karma that accords with suffering.
The good actions of the upper stages, above the three trances, are said to be conducive to neither suffering nor happiness, because above these stages there is no feeling of suffering or happiness.

You should understand that these actions not only bring about feelings as retribution, they also bring about the aggregates that are the support of those feelings, and the term â€œfeelingâ€ here also includes the support.
Other masters say:
In the lower stages there is also action that is conducive to neither suffering nor happiness, because the retribution of the samÄdhi of neither suffering nor happiness is produced by this action.
If this were not so, then the action of the samÄdhi of neither suffering nor happiness would have no retribution.
Or else, there would be no action, because there is no retribution of suffering or happiness.
Other masters say:
This action is able to bring about as its retribution the faculty of pleasure of the fundamental stages.
There is an opinion
that this action does not bring about feeling as retribution.
Both of these opinions contradict the ÅšÄriputrÄbhidharma.
The ÅšÄriputrÄbhidharma says:
Is there any action that brings about retribution as feeling in the mind but not in the body?
It is said:
Yes, namely, good action free of vitarka.
Also, the ÅšÄriputrÄbhidharma says:

He says:

Yes, it is action whose retribution is pleasant, the mind and mental factors whose retribution is painful, and the formations not associated with the mind whose retribution is neither painful nor pleasant.

This proves that there is also action whose retribution is neither of the two in the lower stages. This is because there is no simultaneous maturation of these three kinds of action apart from the realm of desire.
Is this action good or bad?
It is good but inferior.
If this is so, then it contradicts the explanation that good action up to the third stage is called action whose retribution is pleasant and that obtaining a desirable fruit is called good action.
You should know that this explanation is based on the majority of cases.
Since the nature of this action is different from that of feeling, how can it be said to be action whose retribution is pleasant?
Although the nature of action is different from that of pleasant feeling, it can be the cause that benefits pleasant feeling.
Or else, this action is that which is experienced as pleasure.
How can that pleasure experience the action?
because happiness is the result of retribution of this action.
Or, that happiness is what is experienced by this action, because it is able to experience the retribution of happiness.
Just as it is said that the fragrant powder is in accordance with the bath, this should be so.
Therefore, it is called action that accords with the experience of happiness.
It should be understood that action that accords with the other two experiences is also like this.
In general, action that accords with experience is of five kinds:
First, action that accords with experience by nature, which refers to all feelings, as a scripture says:
When experiencing pleasant feelings, one accurately knows that one is experiencing pleasant feelings, and so on at length.
Second, action that accords with experience through association, which refers to all contacts, as a scripture says:
Contact that accords with the experience of happiness, and so on at length.
Third, action that accords with experience through objects, which refers to all objects, as a scripture says:
When the eye sees forms, one only experiences the forms and does not experience craving for forms, and so on at length. Because forms and so on are the objects of feelings.
Fourth, action that accords with experience through retribution, which refers to action that produces retribution, as a scripture says:
Karma to be experienced in the present, and so on, is explained in detail.
Fifth, direct experience and feeling, that is, feeling that is actually occurring. As a sutra explains:
When experiencing pleasant feeling, the other two feelings cease, and so on.

When this pleasant feeling is present, no other feeling can experience this pleasant feeling. It is only said that the actual presence of the essence of pleasant feeling itself is called experiencing pleasant feeling.
Here it only speaks of feeling that is the ripening of karma, because karma can attract the ripening of feeling.
Although the essence of karma and feeling is different, it can still be called feeling that is pleasant and so on.
Such three kinds of karma are either definite or indefinite. What are their characteristics?
Verse:
They are either definite or indefinite. Definite means the three kinds that are experienced in the present life, and so on.
Or it is said that karma is of five kinds. Other masters say it is of four alternatives.
Discussion:
The above-mentioned feeling that is pleasant and so on should be known as each having definite and indefinite differences. Because they are not definitely experienced, they are called indefinite.
There are three kinds of definite retribution:
one is experienced in the present life, the second in the next life, and the third in some subsequent life.
These three kinds of definite retribution together with the above indefinite retribution make up four kinds of karma.

Some people want to make indefinite retribution into two kinds, that is, definite and indefinite with regard to the time of retribution. Together with the three kinds of definite retribution, they make up five kinds. Karma to be experienced in the present life means that karma created in this life ripens in this life.
Karma to be experienced in the next life means that karma created in this life ripens in the second life.
Karma to be experienced in some subsequent life means that karma created in this life ripens in the third life or after.
Other masters say that
karma to be experienced in the present life may also ripen in other lives.
The name of the karma is established according to the first ripening, and it should not be that the result of strong karma is small.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas do not accept this interpretation, because there is karma whose result is near but not superior, or vice versa.
For example, it is like external seeds: after three and a half months, the sunflower produces fruit, but it takes six months for wheat to produce fruit.
The proponents of similes say that karma has four statements:

First, there is karma whose time period is definite but whose ripening is indefinite, namely the three types of karma that are conducive to the present life, etc., which are not necessarily to be experienced.
Second, there is karma whose ripening is definite but whose time period is indefinite, namely indeterminate karma that is definitely to be experienced.
Third, there is karma whose two [time period and ripening] are both definite, namely karma that is conducive to the present life, etc., which is definitely to be experienced.
Fourth, there is karma whose two [time period and ripening] are both indefinite, namely indeterminate karma that is not necessarily to be experienced.
They say that all karma in total becomes eight types, namely that which is conducive to the present life and so on, which each have two types that are definite and indefinite.
Among these distinctions of karma that are explained, the verse says:
The four wholesome [types of karma] may be performed together, but only three attract similar continuation,
In all realms, four types are created, but in hell, wholesome [karma] excludes the present [life].
The non-returner does not create karma to be experienced in the next life in a realm other than that of detachment.
The arhat does not create karma to be experienced in the next life or in a subsequent life, nor does he create karma to be experienced in the desire realm or the peak of existence upon falling away.
The treatise says:
The three types of karma such as that to be experienced in the present life, etc., are only definite or indefinite, making four.
This is said to be good. Here it only shows the definiteness or indefiniteness of time, explaining the characteristics of the four types of karma as taught in the sutras.
Can the four types of karma be produced simultaneously?
It is possible.
How?
After dispatching the three messengers, one personally engages in sexual misconduct, completing them simultaneously.
How many types of karma can attract a similar class of beings?
Only three can attract, excluding that to be experienced in the present life, because the similar class of beings in the present body is attracted by previous karma.
In which realms and destinies can one create how many types of karma?
In all realms and destinies, whether good or evil, one may create all four as appropriate.
This is the general explanation. If we specifically prohibit, in hell one excludes that which is to be experienced in the present life, because there is no pleasant result. The rest are all created.
The name of nonretrogression is firm, and they are in the stage of separation from defilements.
If ordinary beings, except for karma to be experienced after rebirth, can create the remaining three.
The sages doubly exclude karma to be experienced after rebirth and karma to be experienced in subsequent lives, and can create the remaining two.
Ordinary beings who do not retrogress do not have rebirth in the next life or later rebirth in lower realms. Nonretrogressive sages definitely do not have rebirth in lower realms.
According to the realm in which one is born, one may create karma to be experienced in the present life. The creation of indeterminate karma is unrestricted in all realms.

However, if sages have already attained separation from defilements in the desire realm and the peak of existence, although they may retrogress, they still do not create karma to be experienced after rebirth or in subsequent lives. Those who retrogress from that necessarily retrogress from the fruit.
Those who have retrograded from the fruit definitely do not die. This will be explained later.
Do those abiding in the intermediate state also create karma?
They also create.
How?
The verse says:
In the desire realm, the intermediate state can create twenty-two kinds of karma,
All of which are categorized as karma to be experienced in the present life, because the type and class are the same.
The treatise states:
In the desire realm, while in the intermediate state, one may create twenty-two kinds of karma.
That is to say, there are five stages in the intermediate state, five stages in the womb, and five stages after leaving the womb.

While in the intermediate state, one can create karma that will definitely or not definitely lead to the intermediate state, up to old age.

It should be known that the eleven kinds of definite karma created in the intermediate state are all included in karma to be experienced in the present life, because there is no distinction in the class of the same life.
That is to say, this intermediate state and the ten states of its own class are drawn by one karma.
For this reason, karma to be experienced in the intermediate state is not explained separately, because it is drawn by karma to be experienced in the next life, etc.
What are the characteristics of karma to be experienced in the present life, etc.?
The verse says:
Due to heavy afflictions, pure mind, and constant practice,
and arising in the field of merit, the karma of harming one's parents is definite.
The treatise says:
If the karma one creates is due to heavy afflictions, or a pure mind, or is constantly practiced, or arises in the field of merit,
The field of merit refers to the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha, or to superior individuals, referring to those who have attained superior fruits and superior concentrations.

Even if one does not have heavy afflictions or a pure mind, or does not practice constantly, if one creates good or bad karma, or harms one's parents with a light or heavy mind, all of this is included in definite karma, the rest is not definitely experienced.
What are the characteristics of karma that has results in the present life?
The verse says:
Due to the superiority of the field, intention, and certainty in attracting retribution,
and attaining the stage of permanent separation, karma definitely attracts results in the present life.
The treatise says:
As a result of the superiority of the field, it is said that a bhiká¹£u who addressed a bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä« as a woman was transformed into a woman in this very life.
There are many such stories.

Or one who is born in this realm and forever free from the defilements of this realm, with regard to good and bad karma in this realm.
As for karma whose ripening is fixed but whose time is not fixed, this karma will definitely be able to attract a present life result.

If there is karma whose ripening and time are both fixed, then one definitely does not have the meaning of being forever free from defilements, and one will definitely experience the ripening result in another realm.
If one is forever free from defilements, then one does not experience the ripening result.
In what field does one generate karma that is definitely experienced?
The verse says:
With regard to the Buddha and the foremost Sangha, and to the cessation of conflict and the absence of conflict,
The benefits and harms of the field of merit are immediately experienced.
The treatise says:
In this kind of field of merit, for good or evil karma, the result is immediately experienced.
The field of merit refers to the Sangha headed by the Buddha.
From the perspective of the distinctions in individuals, there are five:
First, emerging from the concentration of cessation. This concentration attains the quiescence of the mind, because this concentration's quiescence resembles nirvana.
If one first gives rise to the mind upon emerging from this concentration, it is like one who enters nirvana and then emerges again.
Second, emerging from the concentration of non-contention. In this concentration, there is the superior intention to benefit immeasurable sentient beings as the object.
When emerging from this concentration, the continuum of the body is transformed by being perfumed by immeasurable supreme merits.
Third, emerging from the concentration of loving-kindness. In this concentration, there is the superior intention of bliss for immeasurable sentient beings as the object.
When one emerges from this samÄdhi, the series of oneâ€™s body is perfumed by innumerable supreme merits.

Fourth, emerging from the path of insight. In this path, one eternally severs all the passions that are to be eliminated by the path of insight and attains a superior transmutation of the support. When one emerges from this path, a pure series is produced.

Fifth, emerging from the path of cultivation. In this path, one eternally severses all the passions that are to be eliminated by the path of cultivation and attains a superior transmutation of the support. When one emerges from this path, a pure series is produced.
Therefore these five are called fields of merit.
If one does the work of benefiting or harming in these five states, this action will definitely be able to summon a reward in the present life.

If one emerges from other samÄdhis and other fruits, the samÄdhi that one has cultivated is not superior, and the passions that are to be eliminated by cultivation are not yet eternally extinguished. Therefore the series is not a superior field of merit.

Among the fruits of retribution, feeling is the most important. We must now consider whether there is any action that summons only mental feeling as retribution or that summons bodily feeling but not mental feeling.
There is.
How is this?
The verse states:
It is accepted that all wholesome karma without initial thought only produces mental feelings as retribution.
Evil karma only produces bodily feelings. This is the difference in the retribution of feelings and karma.
The treatise states:

Wholesome karma without initial thought refers to the wholesome karma from the intermediate concentration up to the peak of existence. Among them, that which can produce feelings as retribution should be known to only produce mental feelings and not bodily feelings, because bodily feelings are necessarily accompanied by initial thought and investigation.

It should be known that all unwholesome karma that can produce feelings as retribution only produces bodily feelings and not mental feelings, because the result of unwholesome causes is painful feeling. The painful feeling accompanying the mind
is definitely called sorrow. Sorrow is not retribution, as has been explained before.
When sentient beings' minds go crazy, what consciousness and what realm are the causes?
The verse states:
Crazy minds are only mental consciousness, born from karma, retribution, fear, harm, and sorrow. Excluding the northern continent, they exist in the desire realm.
The treatise states:

The minds of sentient beings become crazed only in the seventh consciousness, manas. If it were in the first six consciousnesses, there would definitely be no madness, because the first six consciousnesses are devoid of discrimination.
There are five causes of madness:

1. The retribution of the karma of sentient beings, that is, using drugs or spells to drive others mad, or forcing others to drink things they do not want, such as poison or alcohol, or frightening birds and animals by displaying awesome power, or setting a great fire to burn mountains and marshes, or digging pits and causing sentient beings to fall into them, or other actions that cause others to lose their memory. As a result of this kind of karma, in the future one will experience a special retribution that causes oneâ€™s mind to become mad.
2. Fright, that is, non-humans manifesting terrifying forms and coming to threaten and intimidate sentient beings, causing them to see and become mentally disturbed.
3. Injury, that is, because of actions that offend non-humans, they become angry and injure oneâ€™s limbs and joints, causing one to become mentally disturbed.
Fourth, by conflict, that is, by the mutual conflict of wind, heat, and phlegm in the body, the great elements are not in harmony and thus cause mental derangement.
Fifth, by sorrow and grief, that is, due to the loss of loved ones and so on, sorrow and grief entangle the mind and thus cause mental derangement, like Vasiá¹£á¹­ha and others.

If mental derangement exists only in the sixth consciousness, and if it is also admitted that mental derangement arises from the retribution of karma, how can the feeling of the mind not be retribution?
We do not say that mental derangement is retribution, but we do say that it arises from retribution.
That is, evil karma produces great elements that are not in equilibrium as retribution. Based on these great elements, the mind then loses its mindfulness, and therefore it is called derangement.

If even the minds of the desire realm heavens can be insane, how much more so the minds of humans and evil destinies?
Hell beings are always insane, because they are oppressed by much suffering.

That is, hell beings are always harmed by various kinds of instruments of torture, which are sharp and difficult to endure. Oppressed by painful feelings, they do not even recognize themselves, much less understand right and wrong.
Therefore, in hell, enemies lament and sigh, running and screaming wildly. There is a text that transmits this.
Among the sages of the desire realm, with the exception of the Buddhas, there may be insane minds due to the disorder of the four elements, but not due to retribution.
If there is a definite karmic result, one must first experience it before one can attain sagehood.
If it is not a definite karma, then by attaining sagehood one can cause it to have no result and no fear, because one transcends the five fears.
There is also no injury, because the noble ones have no nonhuman beings who hate them, and also no sorrow or worry, because they realize the nature of dharmas.
